messageBody:
FYI, here is how you could do this with TestNG:

@DataProvider
public Object[][] algorithms() {
return new Object[][] {
new Object[] { new Algorithm1(), "input1", "expectedresult1" },
new Object[] { new Algorithm2(), "input2", "expectedresult2" },
new Object[] { new Algorithm3(), "input3", "expectedresult3" },
}
}

@Test(dataProvider = "algorithms")
public void verifyAlgorithm(Algorithm a, String input, String result) {
assertEquals(result, a.calculate(input));
}

Isn't it possible to do something similar with JUnit 4?

--
CÃ©dric

On 8/5/07, dmugtasimov <dimasoft2001@...> wrote:
>
> Imagine that there is a class Algorithm and its subclassed Algorithm1,
> Algorithm2, .. Algorithm9. All AlgorithmN classes have the same
> contract (thus they have same methods and these method should supply
> the same output for the same input).
>
> public abstract Algorithm {
> public abstract String calculate(String in);
> }
>
> public Algorithm1 {
> public String calculate(String in) {
> ... method body 1...
> }
> }
>
> public Algorithm2 {
> public String calculate(String in) {
> ... method body 2...
> }
> }
>
> and so on up to 9.
>
> There is test case AlgorithmTestCase extends TestCase.
> public AlgorithmTestCase extends TestCase {
> public void testAlgorithm() {
> Algorithm algorithm = ... Algorithm1..Algorithm9 instance creation
> code ...;
> assertEquals("RESULT1", algorithm.calculate("INPUT1"));
> }
> }
>
> Is it possible using JUnit and how to run AlgorithmTestCase meeting
> the following conditions?
> 1. Each instance of AlgorithmTestCase does test only one Algorithm
> subclass.
> 2. AlgorithmTestCase is run against each Algorithm subclass.
> 3. GUI runner is started only once.
>
> I tried to do that by passing subclass name in system properties, but
> failed. It happens because when I add test case by
> suite.addTestSuite(Class ...) the actual of TestCase is created after
> the last test case is added, so system properties contain the last
> supplied value.
>
>
>
